prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Band 3 is selected for this project as this band contains a lot of molecular lines that are associated with dense gas and star formation activity such as SiO, HCN, HCO$^{+}$. We have studied this ridge with the single dish MOPRA that shows that RCW 106 is very bright in various molecular lines (see Fig. 1; Lo et al. 2011, 2012). We target to the common lines such as: Baseband 1: total bandwidth (1875 MHz) centered between HCOOH and SiOv1 line in order to have images of these two lines to trace hot core and maser activity, as well as continuum emission. Baseband 2: narrow windows targeting SiO v0, H13CN, SiO v2, HNCO to trace thermal emission from shocks, 13C isotopologue of HCN, and maser Baseband 3: narrow windows targeting HNCO, CCH, HCO to trace hot core and PDR emssion Baseband 4: high spectral (0.23km/s) resolution of HCO+ and HCN which focus on tracing the gas column density and also the HCO+/HCN ratio, which is a diagnostic of starburst activity. This baseband has higher spectral resolution in order to trace motion of the dense gas with respect to the cores.
The spectra in several windows are averaged in order to fit with the maximum data rate while keeping reasonable spectral resolutions.

We intend to resolve at least three times the typical dense core size of 0.1 pc, which is also the typical width of interstellar filament. The corresponding linear spatial resolution is 0.1/3 pc. At a distance of 3.6 kpc, this corresponds to 1.9 arcsec.
Since RCW 106 is a dense ridge with large scale emission that have size at least twice larger than the MOPRA beam, we select a LAS of 60arcsec in order to recover all diffuse emission that are associated with the clouds. This LAS also allows us to cover any filament which is as long as 1 pc. Therefore ACA array is needed for this study.

Band 3 is selected for this project as this band contains a lot of molecular lines that are associated with dense gas and star formation activity such as SiO, HCN, HCO+. We have studied this ridge with the single dish MOPRA that shows that RCW 106 is very bright in various molecular lines (see Fig. 1; Lo et al. 2011, 2012). The average main-(36")beam temperature of the HCO+ line observed with MOPRA is ~0.4 K. Assuming that this is coming from a cloud structure of 1/3 of the beamsize due to beam dilution, we esstimated that the emission comes from a source with a brightness temperature of ~3.6 K. Therefore we request an RMS of ~1 K in order to reach a a 3S/N. We note that the peak temperature of the dense cores re much higher than 3.6 K, therefore this sensitivity will allow us to trace the gas emission associated with the dense cores as well as the filamentary network.
We use SiO v=0, J=2-1 line as the representative window and use a spectral resolution of ~ 1 km/s linewidth ~ 10 km/s for sensitivity calculation. This is the typical value measured with MOPRA, and is also consistent with other massive star forming regions.
The total continumm sensitivity of 0.241 mJy will allow us to trace the dense core population down to ~ 0.01 Msun within a core with radius 0.03 ~ pc. This is excellenth to reach our immediate objectives.

We have studied this ridge with the single dish MOPRA that shows that RCW 106 is very bright in various molecular lines (see Fig. 1; Lo et al. 2011, 2012). We target to the common lines such as: Baseband 1: total bandwidth (1875 MHz) centered between HCOOH and SiOv1 line in order to have images of these two lines to trace hot core and maser activity, as well as continuum emission. Baseband 2: narrow windows targeting SiO v0, H13CN, SiO v2, HNCO to trace thermal emission from shocks, 13C isotopologue of HCN, and maser. H13CO+ is alsowithin the SiO window. Baseband 3: narrow windows targeting HNCO, CCH, HCO to trace hot core and PDR emssion Baseband 4: high spectral (0.23km/s) resolution of HCO+ and HCN which focus on tracing the gas column density and also the HCO+/HCN ratio, which is a diagnostic of starburst activity. This baseband has higher spectral resolution in order to trace motion of the dense gas with respect to the cores.
The spectra in several windows are averaged in order to fit with the maximum data rate while keeping reasonable spectral resolutions.

This LAS also allows us to cover any filament which is as long as 1 pc. Therefore ACA array is needed for this study.

Band 3 is selected for this project as this band contains a lot of molecular lines that are associated with dense gas and star formation activity such as SiO, HCN, HCO+. We have studied this ridge with the single dish MOPRA that shows that RCW 106 is very bright in various molecular lines (see Fig. 1; Lo et al. 2011, 2012). The average main-(36")beam temperature of the HCO+ line observed with MOPRA is ~0.4 K. Assuming that this is coming from a cloud structure of 1/3 of the beamsize due to beam dilution, we esstimated that the emission comes from a source with a brightness temperature of ~3.6 K. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Large-scale triggering phenomena such as cloud-cloud collision, converging flows and shock compressions plays an important role in massive star formation. Filamentary network associated with dense ridges are created from such dynamical processes and were shown to host massive star formation. RCW 106 is the most active massive star forming complex in the Southern sky, which exhibit all features that mimic the effects of large-scale triggering processes. Large and complex filamentary/ridge network, massive dense cores, and candidate massive protostars were discovered in RCW 106. Despite being studied extensively, most continuum and molecular line observations were done with a low resolution of 37". We therefore propose to make mosaic maps of continuum and molecular lines at band 3 toward the RCW 106 ridge with a resolution of 1.9" (0.033 pc at 3.6 kpc), adequate to resolve the dense cores with size 0.1 pc. The main goals are (1) to make a census of core populations down to 0.1Msun with associated kinematic information (2) to quantify the impact of large-scale triggering and shock compression from the external environment onto the dense cores.
